Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the mother needs to provide it
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: They have a generous deadline and can refactor the module later
Story:
I sit at my desk, the soft hum of my laptop blending with the distant clatter of dishes from the kitchen. My son’s laughter echoes down the hallway, a reminder of why I push myself so hard. As a mother, I know the bills are piling up—groceries, rent, the electricity bill. My family depends on me to keep us afloat, to make sure there’s always food on the table and a roof over our heads. That’s why I took this job, why I work late into the night.

But as a software developer, I’m expected to do more than just finish tasks. My manager trusts me to write code that’s clean and maintainable, to set a standard for the team. The deadline for this module is generous, and I could take the time to refactor, to make it something I’m proud of. Yet, the thought of overtime pay tugs at me—I could rush through, deliver something that works, and ask for more hours on the next sprint. The money would help, but the code would suffer. My heart pounds as I stare at the screen, torn between my family’s needs and my professional integrity.
